elements.content: A new bifunctional NTB (tris(benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine)-type ligand incorporating coordination discriminable tripodal benzimidazolyl and monodentate pyridyl groups, tris((pyridin-3-ylmethyl)benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (3-TPyMNTB), has been prepared to assemble 4d–4f heterometallic three-dimensional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) in a stepwise route: (1) direct reaction of 3-TPyMNTB with Ln(ClO4)3 affords monomeric complexes [Eu(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3·2.5MeCN (1-Eu) and [Gd(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3·2MeCN·2CHCl3 (1-Gd), and (2) assembly of the precursors 1-Eu and 1- Gd with AgClO4 gives rise to infinite MOFs [EuAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6·4MeCN (2-Eu-Ag) and [GdAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6·4MeCN (2-Gd-Ag), respectively. In monomer 1-Eu, the ligand shows an antenna effect to transfer absorbed energy to Eu3+ center to emit characteristic red luminescence, while in 4d–4f heterometallic MOF 2-Eu-Ag, the ligand centered emission is resensitized by Ag+ ions to generate dual emissions, coming up with the direct white-light emission from a single crystal. The detailed photoluminescent study has been carried out in both solid state and solution to elucidate the emission nature.

In monomer 1-Eu, the ligand shows an antenna effect to transfer absorbed energy to Eu3+ center to emit characteristic red luminescence, while in 4d-4f heterometallic MOF 2-Eu-Ag, the ligand centered emission is resensitized by Ag+ ions to generate dual emissions, coming up with the direct white-light emission from a single crystal. The detailed photoluminescent study has been carried out in both solid state and solution to elucidate the emission nature.

elements.content: Stepwise assembly of LnL2 monomers containing coordination discriminable tripodal benzimidazolyl and monodentate pyridyl groups with the Ag+ ions leads formation of three-dimensional Ag−Eu bimetallic metal−organic frameworks, which are capable of directly generating white-light emission in a single-phase material.
elements.clean_text: Stepwise assembly of LnL2 monomers containing coordination discriminable tripodal benzimidazolyl and monodentate pyridyl groups with the Ag+ ions leads formation of three-dimensional Ag-Eu bimetallic metal-organic frameworks, which are capable of directly generating white-light emission in a single-phase material.

elements.content: White-light-emitting materials and devices have attracted much interest because of their potential applications in, for instance, solid-state lighting (SSL), full-color displays, and backlights. So far, most of the white-light sources depend on the combination of the emissions from separate dopants or multiple components, which may cause some problems such as phase separation and color variation. In contrast, direct white-light emission from a single-component phosphor is expected to avoid such drawbacks, giving rise to white-light sources of higher quality. Therefore, design of single-phase white-light-emitting materials is of obvious interest and importance. The single-component polymer white-light devices by incorporating three (RGB: red–green–blue) or two (blue–orange) organic chromophores or color-tunable metal complexes species have been well demonstrated. Other types of potential single-phase white-light-emitting phosphors have been proposed for the 2D II–VI semiconductor bulk materials or nanocrystals, and the inorganic materials doped with rare earth metal ions. However, single-phase white-light emitters based on metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been seldom achieved, although such metal–organic materials feature easy integration of inorganic and organic properties and straightforward syntheses, and a variety of luminescent MOFs have been investigated for chemical sensing, color tuning, and bioimaging.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

White-light-emitting materials and devices have attracted much interest because of their potential applications in, for instance, solid-state lighting (SSL), full-color displays, and backlights. So far, most of the white-light sources depend on the combination of the emissions from separate dopants or multiple components, which may cause some problems such as phase separation and color variation. In contrast, direct white-light emission from a single-component phosphor is expected to avoid such drawbacks, giving rise to white-light sources of higher quality. Therefore, design of single-phase white-light-emitting materials is of obvious interest and importance. The single-component polymer white-light devices by incorporating three (RGB: red-green-blue) or two (blue-orange) organic chromophores or color-tunable metal complexes species have been well demonstrated. Other types of potential single-phase white-light-emitting phosphors have been proposed for the 2D II-VI semiconductor bulk materials or nanocrystals, and the inorganic materials doped with rare earth metal ions. However, single-phase white-light emitters based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been seldom achieved, although such metal-organic materials feature easy integration of inorganic and organic properties and straightforward syntheses, and a variety of luminescent MOFs have been investigated for chemical sensing, color tuning, and bioimaging.

elements.content: In the photo- and electroluminescence fields, Ln3+ ions are unique owing to their intrinsic electronic properties that can show luminescence in either near-infrared (Yb3+, Nd3+, and Er3+) or visible (Eu3+ and Tb3+) regions. Particularly, studies in d–f heterometallic complexes, including MOFs, are rapidly expanding. Nevertheless, due to the fluxional geometry and high coordination-number of Ln3+ ions, the assembly of d–f heterometallic MOFs from predesigned luminescent Ln-organic precursors with other transition metal ions, in order to obtain SSL materials as color-tunable or white-light-emitting phosphors, still remains a challenge. Recently, Shimizu et al. have assembled an Ln–Ba metal–organic framework in a stepwise manner from luminescent building blocks, achieving predictable photophysical properties. De Cola et al. have reported an Ir–Eu three nuclear complex that shows white-light emission in solution. Although white-light emission has not been realized in the solid state, these examples imply a potential synthetic approach to the single-phase white-light-emitting phosphors through assembly of d–f heterometallic MOFs.

elements.content: Herein, we demonstrate that 4d-4f heterometallic Ag-Ln MOFs (2-Eu-Ag and 2- Gd-Ag) can be obtained from stepwise assembly of the predesigned Ln3+-monomers (1-Eu and 1-Gd) with the Ag+ ions by design of a bifunctional NTB (tris(benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine)-type ligand incorporating tripodal benzimidazolyl (Bim) and monodentate pyridyl (Py) groups (Scheme ). The resulting Eu–Ag bimetallic MOF shows distinct white-light emission through a dual-emitting pathway: the metal-centered (MC) f–f emission characteristic of Eu3+ ion and ligand-centered (LC) excimer emission sensitized by Ag+ ion.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we demonstrate that 4d-4f heterometallic Ag-Ln MOFs (2-Eu-Ag and 2- Gd-Ag) can be obtained from stepwise assembly of the predesigned Ln3+-monomers (1-Eu and 1-Gd) with the Ag+ ions by design of a bifunctional NTB (tris(benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine)-type ligand incorporating tripodal benzimidazolyl (Bim) and monodentate pyridyl (Py) groups (Scheme ). The resulting Eu-Ag bimetallic MOF shows distinct white-light emission through a dual-emitting pathway: the metal-centered (MC) f-f emission characteristic of Eu3+ ion and ligand-centered (LC) excimer emission sensitized by Ag+ ion.

elements.clean_text: 1  Ligand 3-TPyMNTB and Stepwise Assembly of MOFs 2-Ln-Ag from Monomers 1-Ln

elements.content: Our previous work on the ligand tris(benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (NTB) and its N-substituted derivates confirms that this type of tripodal compound could encapsulate Ln3+ ion into a stable LnL2 coordination environment, giving rise to Ln3+ characteristic luminescence. Furthermore, such luminescent LnL2 motifs can be used as building blocks to assemble one- to three-dimensional (1D to 3D) hydrogen-bonded frameworks. Along this line, we have designed a new bifunctional NTB-type ligand, tris((pyridin-3-ylmethyl)benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (3-TPyMNTB), which contains both NTB tripodand and three monodentate pyridyl arms of discriminable coordination behaviors toward Ln3+ and Ag+ ions, and successfully reached stepwise syntheses of Ag-Ln bimetallic 3D MOFs, as shown in Scheme . The ligand 3-PyMNTB was prepared by decorating the NTB ligand through NH substitutions with three 3-pyridyl donor groups. The monomeric complexes [Eu(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3·2.5MeCN (1-Eu) and [Gd(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3·2MeCN·2CHCl3 (1-Gd) were obtained directly from reaction of 3-TPyMNTB with Ln(ClO4)3 in MeCN. By using 1-Eu or 1-Gd as precursors, polymeric MOFs [EuAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6·4MeCN (2-Eu-Ag) and [GdAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6·4MeCN (2-Gd-Ag), respectively, were prepared upon diffusion of AgClO4 in MeCN/CHCl3 (for synthetic and characterization details, see the ). Complexes 1-Eu, 2-Eu-Ag, and 2-Gd-Ag were obtained as single crystals with the structures unambiguously analyzed by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction and the phase purity of bulk samples identified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figure S1 in the ) measurements. The chemical composition of complex 1-Gd was verified by elemental analysis. The crystals of all complexes contain solvents molecules locating in the cavities of the crystal lattice. When exposing the crystals in the open air, parts of the lattice solvents may escape; however, the crystals retain their crystallinity and integrity, as confirmed by the PXRD measurements, so the photochemistry was studied directly by using the as-grown crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure

Our previous work on the ligand tris(benzimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (NTB) and its N-substituted derivates confirms that this type of tripodal compound could encapsulate Ln3+ ion into a stable LnL2 coordination environment, giving rise to Ln3+ characteristic luminescence. Furthermore, such luminescent LnL2 motifs can be used as building blocks to assemble one- to three-dimensional (1D to 3D) hydrogen-bonded frameworks. Along this line, we have designed a new bifunctional NTB-type ligand, tris((pyridin-3-ylmethyl)benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (3-TPyMNTB), which contains both NTB tripodand and three monodentate pyridyl arms of discriminable coordination behaviors toward Ln3+ and Ag+ ions, and successfully reached stepwise syntheses of Ag-Ln bimetallic 3D MOFs, as shown in Scheme . The ligand 3-PyMNTB was prepared by decorating the NTB ligand through NH substitutions with three 3-pyridyl donor groups. The monomeric complexes [Eu(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3⋅2.5MeCN (1-Eu) and [Gd(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3⋅2MeCN⋅2CHCl3 (1-Gd) were obtained directly from reaction of 3-TPyMNTB with Ln(ClO4)3 in MeCN. By using 1-Eu or 1-Gd as precursors, polymeric MOFs [EuAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6⋅4MeCN (2-Eu-Ag) and [GdAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6⋅4MeCN (2-Gd-Ag), respectively, were prepared upon diffusion of AgClO4 in MeCN/CHCl3 (for synthetic and characterization details, see the ). Complexes 1-Eu, 2-Eu-Ag, and 2-Gd-Ag were obtained as single crystals with the structures unambiguously analyzed by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction and the phase purity of bulk samples identified by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, Figure S1 in the ) measurements. The chemical composition of complex 1-Gd was verified by elemental analysis. The crystals of all complexes contain solvents molecules locating in the cavities of the crystal lattice. When exposing the crystals in the open air, parts of the lattice solvents may escape; however, the crystals retain their crystallinity and integrity, as confirmed by the PXRD measurements, so the photochemistry was studied directly by using the as-grown crystals.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray structural analysis of the ligand 3-TPyMNTB verified substitution of all three NH protons by 3-pyridyl groups (Figure S2, ). In the crystal lattice, the ligands are packed via formation of intermolecular offset π–π stacking (centroid-to-centroid distances: 3.217–3.386 Å) and C–H···π interactions (H···π distance: 2.863 Å) between Bim and Py rings, respectively, as depicted in Figure S3, . The single-crystal analyses also confirmed discrete LnL2 monomer in 1-Eu and 3D infinite frameworks in 2-Eu-Ag and 2-Gd-Ag (hereafter named as 2-Ln-Ag). The two 3D MOFs are isostructural, displaying identical network connectivity and crystal packing. In both monomeric precursor 1-Eu and polymeric MOFs 2-Ln-Ag, a rather similar LnL2 coordination unit [Ln(3-TPyMNTB)2]3+ was revealed, where the Ln3+ ion is hosted in the cavity of two sandwiched tripodands as shown in Figure a and Figure S4 in the . Such LnL2 structural unit provides a well-shielding environment for Ln3+ center through formation of LnN8 cubic coordination sphere and intramolecular π–π interactions (centroid-to-centroid distances: 3.170–3.522 Å) between six surrounding Bim rings of two face-to-face arranged ligands (Figure S5, ). In monomer 1-Eu, the pyridyl N donors (NPy) are free of coordination, while in MOFs 2-Ln-Ag, the LnL2 unit acts as building block to be linked via the Ag–NPy bonding to six Ag+ ions (Figure b), resulting in an infinite 3D framework (Figure c). Each Ag+ ion joins two different LnL2 units and further involves solvent molecules in coordination, giving rise to three types of coordination geometries: linear AgN2 for Ag1, trigonal AgN2N′ (N′ atom from CH3CN molecule) for Ag2, and T-shape AgN2O (O atom from water molecule) for Ag3. If we define the LnL2 unit as six-connecting node, and Ag+ ion as two-connecting linker, the 3D framework of 2-Ln-Ag can be simplified into a noninterpenetrating α-Po topology (41263–pcu (primitive cubic), Figure S6, ). The solvents and anions occupy the cavities of the 3D framework, making the overall structure nonporous. Above structural analyses support the finding in synthetic procedure that the predesigned monomers 1-Ln can act as viable precursors to be assembled via Ag+–bonding into bimetallic 4d–4f MOFs 2-Ln-Ag (Scheme ). It is also worthy of note that, in the crystal lattice, the intermolecular π–π interactions (centroid-to-centroid distances: 3.331–3.743 Å) are formed between Py rings from the neighboring LnL2 units (Figure S7, ). Therefore, both intra- (Bim–Bim) and intermolecular (Py–Py) π–π stacking are present in monomer 1-Eu and MOFs 2-Ln-Ag, which will play important roles in their photoluminescence (PL) properties.

elements.content: The room-temperature solid-state photoluminescent (PL) emission spectra of the free ligand 3-TPyMNTB, Eu3+ monomeric complex 1-Eu, and Ag+-Eu3+ polymeric MOF 2–Eu-Ag are shown in Figure . For comparison, a Gd3+ monomeric complex 1-Gd similar to 1-Eu and a Ag+-Gd3+ polymeric MOF 2-Gd-Ag similar to 2-Eu-Ag have been prepared, and their solid-state PL spectra are also shown in Figure . The free ligand 3-TPyMNTB displays weak luminescence with a wide band centered around 530 and a shoulder at 375 nm. In monomer 1-Eu these ligand-centered (LC) emissions are significantly suppressed. Instead, a series of sharp peaks characteristic of Eu3+ luminescence appear at 579, 592, 614, 649, and 695 nm, corresponding to the 5D0→7FJ (J = 0–4) transitions, respectively. The lifetime τ = 194 μs at 614 nm and quantum yield Φ = 1.4% are comparable with the metal-centered (MC) emissions of previously reported Eu3+ complexes of the analogous NTB tripodal ligands. The diminished LC emission in 1-Eu indicates that antenna effect occurs, that is, energy migration takes place upon ligand absorption, followed by intersystem crossing S1→T1 and antenna T1→f transfer, and then generating f–f emissions of Eu3+ ion. However, the low quantum yield suggests that the S1→T1 and/or T1→f energy transfer may not be of good efficiency, or there are nonradiative deactivation processes during f–f emission.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Study

The room-temperature solid-state photoluminescent (PL) emission spectra of the free ligand 3-TPyMNTB, Eu3+ monomeric complex 1-Eu, and Ag+-Eu3+ polymeric MOF 2-Eu-Ag are shown in Figure . For comparison, a Gd3+ monomeric complex 1-Gd similar to 1-Eu and a Ag+-Gd3+ polymeric MOF 2-Gd-Ag similar to 2-Eu-Ag have been prepared, and their solid-state PL spectra are also shown in Figure . The free ligand 3-TPyMNTB displays weak luminescence with a wide band centered around 530 and a shoulder at 375 nm. In monomer 1-Eu these ligand-centered (LC) emissions are significantly suppressed. Instead, a series of sharp peaks characteristic of Eu3+ luminescence appear at 579, 592, 614, 649, and 695 nm, corresponding to the 5D0→7FJ (J = 0-4) transitions, respectively. The lifetime τ = 194 μs at 614 nm and quantum yield Φ = 1.4% are comparable with the metal-centered (MC) emissions of previously reported Eu3+ complexes of the analogous NTB tripodal ligands. The diminished LC emission in 1-Eu indicates that antenna effect occurs, that is, energy migration takes place upon ligand absorption, followed by intersystem crossing S1→T1 and antenna T1→f transfer, and then generating f-f emissions of Eu3+ ion. However, the low quantum yield suggests that the S1→T1 and/or T1→f energy transfer may not be of good efficiency, or there are nonradiative deactivation processes during f-f emission.

elements.content: Emission spectra excited at 298 K in the solid state (λex = 310 nm): (a) 3-TPyMNTB ligand, (b) 1-Gd monomer, (c) 2-Gd-Ag MOF, (d) 1-Eu monomer, and (e) 2–Eu-Ag MOF. The inserts show the CIE color coordinates (black dots) of the white light of 2-Eu-Ag excited at different λex and an emission photo of 2-Eu-Ag excited at 310 nm with a 450 W xenon lamp.

The inserts show the CIE color coordinates (black dots) of the white light of 2-Eu-Ag excited at different λex and an emission photo of 2-Eu-Ag excited at 310 nm with a 450 W xenon lamp.

elements.content: By contrast, the PL emission spectrum of the MOF 2-Eu-Ag features in observation of two kinds of luminescence. One is the characteristic Eu3+ sharp emissions from 5D0→7FJ transitions (τ = 122 μs at 614 nm) similar to those in 1-Eu, and the other is a broad emission centered around 510 nm. This broad emission of 2-Eu-Ag is apparently reminiscent of the broad LC emission from the ligand 3-TPyMNTB, which has been nearly quenched in monomer 1-Eu but obviously resensitized in 2-Eu-Ag, indicating that assembly of monomer 1-Eu by Ag+ ion causes distinctive photoluminescent property in Ag–Eu bimetallic MOF (vide post).
elements.clean_text: By contrast, the PL emission spectrum of the MOF 2-Eu-Ag features in observation of two kinds of luminescence. One is the characteristic Eu3+ sharp emissions from 5D0→7FJ transitions (τ = 122 μs at 614 nm) similar to those in 1-Eu, and the other is a broad emission centered around 510 nm. This broad emission of 2-Eu-Ag is apparently reminiscent of the broad LC emission from the ligand 3-TPyMNTB, which has been nearly quenched in monomer 1-Eu but obviously resensitized in 2-Eu-Ag, indicating that assembly of monomer 1-Eu by Ag+ ion causes distinctive photoluminescent property in Ag-Eu bimetallic MOF (vide post).

elements.content: A striking feature is that the combination of these two kinds of luminescence in MOF 2-Eu-Ag leads to the overall white-light emission. A representative emission photo excited at 310 nm with a 450 W xenon lamp, as well as a 1931 Commission Internationale de L’Eclairage (CIE) diagram showing the chromaticity coordinates of the white light excited at varied wavelengths are illustrated in Figure and Figure S8 in the . It was found that, when excited from 310 to 370 nm, the calculated chromaticity coordinates of white light ranged from (0.42, 0.32) to (0.45, 0.37), just falling within the white region of the 1931 CIE chromaticity diagram. This verifies that the white-light emitting from 2-Eu-Ag is balanced on synergetic contributions from MC and LC dual emissions, because the excitations at different wavelengths will definitely give rise to different emission intensity relativity of these two kinds of luminescence, thus causing shift of the chromaticity coordinate in the 1931 CIE diagram. As a consequence, the chromaticity coordinates of white light are depending on the excitation wavelength (λex), enabling a potential approach to regulate the white-light property by means of such dual-emissive single-phase compound.

As a consequence, the chromaticity coordinates of white light are depending on the excitation wavelength (λex), enabling a potential approach to regulate the white-light property by means of such dual-emissive single-phase compound.

elements.content: To clarify the origin of the wide LC band in 2-Eu-Ag, the PL emission spectrum of the Gd3+ monomer 1-Gd analogous to 1-Eu has also been recorded (Figure b). It is clear that the emission spectral profiles of the ligand and Gd3+ monomer are closely resembling, except that the maxima of the broad bands shift from 530 nm in free ligand to 495 nm in 1-Gd monomer. Because the emissive state of Gd3+ (>31000 cm–1) is typically well above the emissive ligand levels, which prevents the LC-to-MC energy transfer, the emission nature of the 1-Gd monomer can be regarded as metal-perturbed LC emission of the free ligand. From Figure , we can see that the broad emission in MOF 2-Eu-Ag rather resembles the broad emission in 1-Gd monomer, apparently indicative of the same LC emission nature. To further testify this assignment, the MOF 2-Gd-Ag analogous to 2-Eu-Ag was also prepared and its PL emission spectrum was recorded as Figure c. The spectral shape of 2-Gd-Ag is similar to those of free ligand and 1-Gd monomer, showing a relatively enhanced broad emission around 510 nm which is located at the same position as in 1-Eu-Ag. Based on the fact that 1-Eu-Ag and 1-Gd-Ag have isomorphic structure and the same broad emission, assignment of this broad band to LC emission origin is reliable.
elements.clean_text: To clarify the origin of the wide LC band in 2-Eu-Ag, the PL emission spectrum of the Gd3+ monomer 1-Gd analogous to 1-Eu has also been recorded (Figure b). It is clear that the emission spectral profiles of the ligand and Gd3+ monomer are closely resembling, except that the maxima of the broad bands shift from 530 nm in free ligand to 495 nm in 1-Gd monomer. Because the emissive state of Gd3+ (>31000 cm-1) is typically well above the emissive ligand levels, which prevents the LC-to-MC energy transfer, the emission nature of the 1-Gd monomer can be regarded as metal-perturbed LC emission of the free ligand. From Figure , we can see that the broad emission in MOF 2-Eu-Ag rather resembles the broad emission in 1-Gd monomer, apparently indicative of the same LC emission nature. To further testify this assignment, the MOF 2-Gd-Ag analogous to 2-Eu-Ag was also prepared and its PL emission spectrum was recorded as Figure c. The spectral shape of 2-Gd-Ag is similar to those of free ligand and 1-Gd monomer, showing a relatively enhanced broad emission around 510 nm which is located at the same position as in 1-Eu-Ag. Based on the fact that 1-Eu-Ag and 1-Gd-Ag have isomorphic structure and the same broad emission, assignment of this broad band to LC emission origin is reliable.

elements.content: The following question may be: is this broad emission fluorescence or phosphorescence in character? Because of their high emissive state to hinder from T1→f energy transfer, the Gd3+ complexes are often selected to evaluate the excited triplet T1 state due to possible observation of T1→S0 phosphorescence. To elucidate this problem, we carried out the time-resolved PL decay dynamics study. The results reveal that both the 1-Gd monomer and 2-Gd-Ag MOF display biexponential decay feature, offering a longer-lived lifetime τ = 5.6 ns and a shorter-lived lifetime τ = 1.5 ns for 1-Gd monomer, and two analogous lifetimes τ = 6.5 and =2.1 ns for 2-Gd-Ag MOF, which are comparable to those found for the free ligand (τ = 4.7 and 1.3 ns). In addition, the similar biexponential lifetimes (τ = 5.6 and 1.3 ns) have been obtained for the wide emission of 2-Eu-Ag MOF. Since these lifetimes are all within nanoseconds time scale, attribution to the lowest LC triplet state 3ππ* can be definitely ruled out, confirming that the broad emissions, no matter for the free ligand or for the monomeric and polymeric complexes, are all of LC fluorescence character. This means that the phosphorescence of Gd3+ complexes cannot be observed at ambient temperature. However, at low temperature, phosphorescence of 2-Gd-Ag appears as shown in Figure , displaying a wider band around 420 nm with several shoulders enveloped and confirmed by the long lifetimes (τ = 5.5 and 1.4 ms). This gives an estimated triplet state T1 average value of 23810 cm–1, comparable with our previously observed values of the Gd3+ complexes with NTB derivated ligands. To understand the origin of the shoulder peaks on the phosphorescence spectrum, the time-resolved emission spectra of 2-Gd-Ag were measured at 40 K with different excitation delays. As seen from Figure , the delayed emission spectra of 2-Gd-Ag after excitation for 0.1 to 0.45 ms display only one salient band around 410 nm with shoulder peaks significantly diminished, evidently indicates that these shoulder peaks are derived from short-lived fluorescence. In contrast, the phosphorescence of the 1-Gd monomer was not able to observe even at low temperature. This finding, together with the observation of the coexistence of phosphorescence and fluorescence in 2-Gd-Ag at 40 K, suggests that the intersystem crossing S1→T1 transfer and/or the transition forbidden T1→S0 emission in present Gd3+ complexes are unsatisfactorily efficient, leading to poor phosphorescence.

elements.content: From above discussion we can conclude that the broad emission appearing in room-temperature emission spectrum of 2-Eu-Ag MOF originates in LC fluorescence. The blue shift of the band maxima from 530 nm (free ligand) to 510 nm (2-Ln-Ag) may be due to decreased electronic delocalization caused by the ligand conformation restriction upon coordination. The ligands in all complexes take in similar C 3 -tripodal conformation, thus reducing the intermolecular π–π interactions in comparison with the free ligand which gives freedom to all Bim and Py rings to form more extended and variable π–π stacking and C–H···π interactions. Especially, in 1-Gd monomer, six Py groups from two 3-TPyMNTB ligands are freely rotatable along methylene joints, thus further decreasing π–π interactions to shift broad band to 495 nm.

The blue shift of the band maxima from 530 nm (free ligand) to 510 nm (2-Ln-Ag) may be due to decreased electronic delocalization caused by the ligand conformation restriction upon coordination. The ligands in all complexes take in similar C 3  -tripodal conformation, thus reducing the intermolecular π-π interactions in comparison with the free ligand which gives freedom to all Bim and Py rings to form more extended and variable π-π stacking and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. Especially, in 1-Gd monomer, six Py groups from two 3-TPyMNTB ligands are freely rotatable along methylene joints, thus further decreasing π-π interactions to shift broad band to 495 nm.

elements.content: In addition, such rotation freedom will cause nonradiative deactivation processes and affects intersystem crossing S1→T1 and T1→f energy transfer, accounting for undetectable phosphorescence of 1-Gd and low quantum yield of 1-Eu f–f emission. However, when 1-Ln monomers are assembled by Ag+ ions into 3D MOFs, all Py groups are fixed and all components are integrated into a overall rigid structure, which is helpful to reduce various nonradiative decays, facilitating both intraligand and ligand-to-metal transitions, thereof benefiting both LC and MC emissions. Moreover, the Ag+ ion in coordination polymers is often expected to induce a heavy-atom effect to promote intersystem crossing S1→T1 energy transfer. These contributions may be the reason that the broad emission in 2-Gd-Ag is remarkably enhanced and the phosphorescence becomes observable at low temperature. However, the room-temperature phosphorescence of 2-Gd-Ag is still imperceptible because the heavy-atom effect of Ag+ ion is believed to strongly transmit to the ligand only if the Ag–ligand bond is sufficiently covalent (for example Ag–P bond). On the other hand, even the T1→f antenna effect takes the advantage of the structural rigidity endowed by Ag+ ions assembly, the large energy gap between the excited triplet state T1 (23810 cm–1) and 5D0 level of Eu3+ (17500 cm–1) exceeds the optimal ligand-to-metal transfer process, which, according to the Latva’s empirical rule, requires a favorable ΔE(3ππ*–5D0) of ∼2500 cm–1. This means that the role of Ag+ ion in the luminescence of 2-Eu-Ag is most likely to solidify the whole coordination framework, providing Ag-perturbed 1ππ* singlet and 3ππ* triplet states, which are preferable to all radiative transitions than those in 2-Eu monomer. However, the influence on the intraligand 1ππ* singlet transition to resensitize LC emission is apparently more important. This is evident from observation of the enhanced LC emission in 2-Gd-Ag, and also reflected by the relatively shorter lifetime of MC emission (τ = 122 μs) of 2-Eu-Ag than that (τ = 194 μs) of 1-Eu.

elements.content: There remains a question as to why there are two overlapping but distant emission peaks displaying biexponential decay feature in free ligand, 1-Gd, and 2-Gd-Ag emission spectra. In an effort to clear the excited state nature and energy transfer pathways in the ligand and metal complexes, the solution emission spectra of the ligand 3-TPyMNTB have been studied at varied concentrations (Figure ).

elements.content: It is noticeable that the line shape and peak of the ligand emission spectra changed dramatically along with concentration increase. In dilute CH3CN solution, the emission spectra show structured profile, displaying image relationship to the excitation spectra. This means that the dilute solution emission is attributable to the singlet excited state 1ππ* of the “single ligand molecule”, confirmed by its mono-exponential lifetime (τ = 6.7 ns). When the concentration is increased, the well-resolved emission peaks merge into a broad structureless peak around 370 nm. Moreover, a lower-energy peak around 500 nm gradually appears and becomes dominant at high concentrations. In solid state, the spectra evolve into a wide band centered around 530 nm with a shoulder at 375 nm. Because the lower-energy peak around 530 nm has a large Stokes shift (>180 nm), formation of 1(EE)* excimer with origin of π–π interactions is usually expected. Since the molecule 3-TPyMNTB contains three Bim rings and three Py rings, the strong tendency to formation of efficient π–π interactions in concentrated solution and solid-state is understandable (see crystal structure discussion). Furthermore, this broad emission exhibits a bathochromic shift from solution to solid state, which conforms with the normal expectation of more extended π–π delocalization in solid state than in solution. Therefore, the emission spectra of the ligand in solid state can be interpreted as following: the higher-energy shoulder at 375 nm is mainly assignable to the singlet excited state 1ππ* of 3-TPyMNTB molecule, while the lower-energy broad peak at 530 nm is mainly contributed by the excimer originated from π–π interactions. Similar explanation is also applicable to the corresponding emission peaks in the monomeric and polymeric complexes, evidenced by observations of various π–π interactions in their crystal lattice and biexponential lifetimes in their time-solved decay dynamics. The comparable excimer emission from metal coordination polymer has also been reported by others.

elements.content: On the basis of above the discussion, a potential white-light emission pathway is proposed in Scheme for the 4d–4f bimetallic MOF 2-Eu-Ag. There are two kinds of emissive centers provided by 2-Eu-Ag. One is Eu3+-centered f–f emission coming from the antenna effect, and the other is Ag+-sensitized LC emission originating in 1(EE)* excimer. The Ag+ ions play important roles in managing the dual emissions to come up with the white-light emitting from a single-phase material, which may be summarize as the following: (a) assemble the luminescent 1-Eu monomers into a rigid 3D framework to reduce the nonradiative deactivation processes, (b) perturb the excited 1ππ* singlet and 3ππ* triplet states to facilitate both intersystem crossing S1→T1 and antenna T1→f energy transfer, and most importantly, (c) resensitize the 1(EE)* excimer emission that has been quenched in monomer 1-Eu.

elements.clean_text: 2  Representation of Dual-Emitting Pathways in 2-Eu-Ag Generating White-Light Emission

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated first a stepwise approach to synthesis of 4d–4f heterometallic metal–organic framework by predesign of luminescent Eu-organic precursors followed by assembly with Ag+ ions. The resulting bimetallic MOF 2-Eu-Ag is capable of directly generating white light via a dual-emitting pathway by a single-phase phosphor, which may feature advantages over multicomponent white-light materials in (a) the structure is uniform and can be exactly identified, (b) the material can be readily prepared taking advantage of well established supramolecular assembly method, and (c) the optical property is tailorable by design of ligand and selection of metal ion. The solid-state and solution photoluminescence of relevant 1-Ln monomers and 2-Ln-Ag MOFs have been thoroughly investigated to understand the emission nature and energy migration mechanism. Investigations on electroluminescence for 2-Eu-Ag, as well as efforts to optimize the energy transfer process and improve the color quality are currently in progress.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have demonstrated first a stepwise approach to synthesis of 4d-4f heterometallic metal-organic framework by predesign of luminescent Eu-organic precursors followed by assembly with Ag+ ions. The resulting bimetallic MOF 2-Eu-Ag is capable of directly generating white light via a dual-emitting pathway by a single-phase phosphor, which may feature advantages over multicomponent white-light materials in (a) the structure is uniform and can be exactly identified, (b) the material can be readily prepared taking advantage of well established supramolecular assembly method, and (c) the optical property is tailorable by design of ligand and selection of metal ion. The solid-state and solution photoluminescence of relevant 1-Ln monomers and 2-Ln-Ag MOFs have been thoroughly investigated to understand the emission nature and energy migration mechanism. Investigations on electroluminescence for 2-Eu-Ag, as well as efforts to optimize the energy transfer process and improve the color quality are currently in progress.

elements.content: 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Varian/Mercury-Plus 300 instrument. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm–1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å). The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Emission spectra and lifetimes were taken on an EDINBURGH/FLS920 spectrometer using Xenon flash lamp and laser as light sources.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Physical Methods

 1H NMR spectra were measured on a Varian/Mercury-Plus 300 instrument. Infrared (IR) spectra were measured on a Nicolet/Nexus-670 FT-IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were recorded on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å). The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. Emission spectra and lifetimes were taken on an EDINBURGH/FLS920 spectrometer using Xenon flash lamp and laser as light sources.

elements.content:
The ligand tris((pyridin-3-ylmethyl) benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (3-TPyMNTB) was prepared following a literature method by substituting NTB with 2-chloromethyl pyridine. See details in the .

Monomeric Complexes

The monomers [Ln(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3·solvents (Ln = Eu3+, 1-Eu and Gd3+, 1-Gd) were prepared in a general procedure: mixing 0.025 mmol hydrated Ln(ClO4)3 with 0.05 mmol 3-TPyMNTB in CH3CN (or CH3CN–CHCl3, v/v = 1:1) to result in a clear mixture. Slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the mixture gives products. See details in the .
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

Ligand 3-TPyMNTB

The ligand tris((pyridin-3-ylmethyl) benzoimidazol-2-ylmethyl)amine (3-TPyMNTB) was prepared following a literature method by substituting NTB with 2-chloromethyl pyridine. See details in the .

Monomeric Complexes

The monomers [Ln(3-TPyMNTB)2](ClO4)3⋅solvents (Ln = Eu3+, 1-Eu and Gd3+, 1-Gd) were prepared in a general procedure: mixing 0.025 mmol hydrated Ln(ClO4)3 with 0.05 mmol 3-TPyMNTB in CH3CN (or CH3CN-CHCl3, v/v = 1:1) to result in a clear mixture. Slow diffusion of diethyl ether into the mixture gives products. See details in the .

elements.content: Caution! Perchlorate salts of metal complexes with organic ligands are potential explosives. While we have encountered no incidents in the preparations, it is advisable to use only small amounts and to handle the compounds with caution.

elements.content: The MOFs [LnAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6·solvents (Ln = Eu3+, 1-Eu-Ag and Gd3+, 1-Gd-Ag) were prepared in a stepwise way: (1) dissolving 0.025 mmol hydrated Ln(ClO4)3 and 0.05 mmol 3-TPyMNTB in CH3CN leading to formation of monomer 1 and (2) diffusing monomer 1 in CH3CN slowly into a CH3CN–CHCl3 (v/v = 1:1) solution containing 0.075 mmol AgClO4 by means of layering method, giving rise to the assembly of polymers. See details in the .

MOF Complexes

The MOFs [LnAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6⋅solvents (Ln = Eu3+, 1-Eu-Ag and Gd3+, 1-Gd-Ag) were prepared in a stepwise way: (1) dissolving 0.025 mmol hydrated Ln(ClO4)3 and 0.05 mmol 3-TPyMNTB in CH3CN leading to formation of monomer 1 and (2) diffusing monomer 1 in CH3CN slowly into a CH3CN-CHCl3 (v/v = 1:1) solution containing 0.075 mmol AgClO4 by means of layering method, giving rise to the assembly of polymers. See details in the .

cln_elements.clean_text:
MOF Complexes

The MOFs [LnAg3(3-TPyMNTB)2(H2O)(MeCN)](ClO4)6⋅solvents (Ln = Eu3+, 1-Eu-Ag and Gd3+, 1-Gd-Ag) were prepared in a stepwise way: (1) dissolving 0.025 mmol hydrated Ln(ClO4)3 and 0.05 mmol 3-TPyMNTB in CH3CN leading to formation of monomer 1 and (2) diffusing monomer 1 in CH3CN slowly into a CH3CN-CHCl3 (v/v = 1:1) solution containing 0.075 mmol AgClO4 by means of layering method, giving rise to the assembly of polymers. See details in the .
